item.content:encoded: I really enjoyed @ReustleMatt interview with @Speedwell_LLC. While none of this is quite new info, just listening (or reading) to it still feels oddly revealing what the investment "research" has evolved to. Great episode.
item.author: Mostly Borrowed Ideas

item.content:encoded: This moment is, literally, what we've always been told 400,000,000 guns in private hands were for. The reason we had to just get over school shootings, domestic violence, sky high suicide rates. If not here, now, to stop this, then why did we have to suffer through all the rest?
item.author: Patrick S. Tomlinson

item.content:encoded: Trump‚Äôs aggressive stance toward Canada comes out of left field for most Americans, but @scoopercooper reporting in The Bureau consistently shows that top levels of Canadian govt and law enforcement may be widely compromised by organized crime & the CCP. The Bureau is Must-Read
item.author: MuddyWatersResearch

item.content:encoded: In a large US sample, approximately half of all women discontinue antidepressant usage during pregnancy (no change in usage for spouses). This is in a new paper that I just published with @claireeboone and @ccolina_pe that is primarily descriptive.
item.author: Devin Pope

item.content:encoded: Finally in print! The idea of writing a paper about the minimum wage was pretty scary. I'm glad we did. We learned a lot. We hope you do too! The appendix and replication package, including tex files is on my website. Thanks to @ChadJonesEcon, who was an excellent editor.
item.author: Simon Mongey

item.content:encoded: President Trump‚Äôs Kennedy Center announcement appears to be blatantly illegal. U.S. Code says general trustees ‚Äúshall hold office ‚Ä¶ for a term of 6 years‚Äù - nothing about the President having power to remove - and the Chairperson is appointed by the Board. A president cannot

item.content:encoded: Spouse switched regular coffee with decaf w/o telling me, then followed up later w/ some data collection (which I mistook for a sign of care & interest). Calling the IRB.

item.content:encoded:
The US government has now gutted all of the tools created to fight kleptocracy. It's going to be up to other democracies to save their political and financial systems from anonymous flows of cash.
https://t.co/a3BbrttFec
item.author: Anne Applebaum

item.content:encoded: I don't get the deregulation push. We generally don't regulate firms in the U.S. economy. Not Big Tech, nor telecom, cable, airlines, ride share. Utilities are regulated. Banks are barely. We've rescinded regulations since Carter, and we've refrained from adopting new regulations
item.author: Hal Singer

item.content:encoded: "For example, if we compare 2002 to 2022 ‚Äì an even twenty years, and a timeframe with more reliable starting data than 1998 ‚Äì Internet traffic increased by a factor of 1,000 while the price of transit decreased by a factor of 1,000. We could call that Jevons‚Ä¶ Flatline?"

item.content:encoded: Musk is leading a war on workers, and in this issue, The Economist is cheering him on. In this work from home (WHF) piece, the corporatist magazine endorses the idea of reducing a worker‚Äôs wage if she elects to work remotely. All rationalized by a fancy economic study!!

item.content:encoded: New post! Looking at three recent papers on the productivity impacts of government funded research, both in the US and OECD. Across different methods, all find positive impacts.

item.content:encoded: If Musk and Trump openly defy lower courts just remember the precedent the prior admin pursued to lose more money. And note this was the Supreme Court, after its ruling against him.
